title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
random_vars <- readRDS("D:/TU Hamburg/Semester_5/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
View(random_vars)


n = 1000
mean_age <- mean(random_vars[1:n,"age"])
mean_income <- mean(random_vars[1:n,"income"])

print(paste("Expected age value =", mean_age, "Expected income value =", mean_income))

#> [1] "Expected age value = 33.471 Expected income value = 3510.731"



age_variance <- var(random_vars[1:n,"age"])
income_variance <- var(random_vars[1:n,"income"])

print(paste("Variance age value =", age_variance, "Variance income value =", income_variance))

#> [1] "Variance age value = 340.607766766767 Variance income value = 8625645.84448348"



age_sd <- sd(random_vars[1:n,"age"])
income_sd <- sd(random_vars[1:n,"income"])

print(paste("standard deviation age value =", age_sd, "standard deviation income value =", income_sd))

#> [1] "standard deviation age value = 18.4555619466536 standard deviation income value = 2936.94498492626"


2 -I do not think it makes sense to compare both values together as the income values is in thousands, however, the maximum age number is in hundreds. Therefore, they have different value domains that they can range in.

covariance <- cov(random_vars[1:n,"age"],random_vars[1:n,"income"])
corelation <- cor(random_vars[1:n,"age"],random_vars[1:n,"income"])

print(paste("covariance value =",covariance, "corelarion value =", corelation))

#> [1] "covariance value = 29700.1468458458 corelarion value = 0.547943162326477"


4 - correlation is easier to interpret as it is a standardized form of covariance, as its values bounded between -1 and 1. One can understand from the correlation result, that income and age are binded by a linear relation with a slope of 0.54.

library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

income_at_age_18 <- random_vars %>%
  filter(age<=18)
mean_income_at_age_18 <- mean(income_at_age_18$income)

print(paste("Conditional_Expected_value:income at age<= 18:",mean_income_at_age_18))

#> [1] "Conditional_Expected_value:income at age<= 18: 389.607438016529"



library(dplyr)
income_at_age_18_65 <- random_vars %>%
  filter(age>=18 & age<=65)
mean_income_at_age_18_65 = mean(income_at_age_18_65$income)

print(paste("Conditional_Expected_value:income at age>=18 and age <= 65:",mean_income_at_age_18_65))

#> [1] "Conditional_Expected_value:income at age>=18 and age <= 65: 4691.3779637378"



library(dplyr)
income_at_age_65 <- random_vars %>%
  filter(age>=65)
mean_income_at_age_65 = mean(income_at_age_65$income)

print(paste("Conditional_Expected_value:income at age >= 65:",mean_income_at_age_65))

#> [1] "Conditional_Expected_value:income at age >= 65: 1777.23728813559"

data <- read.csv("D:/TU Hamburg/Semester_5/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics/Swimming Pool Drowning Correlating with Films Nicolas Cage Appeared in.csv")


library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data = data,aes(x = Swimming.Pool.Drownings, y =  Nicholas.Cage)) +  
geom_line()

title: Probability Theory
text:
Assignment I:

pscope <- 0.3
pscope_time <- 0.2
Pnscope_time <- 0.6


p_time_and_scope <-  pscope * pscope_time

p_time_and_nscope <- (1-pscope) * (1-Pnscope_time)

p_ntime_and_scope <- pscope * (1- pscope_time)

p_ntime_and_nscope <- (1 -pscope) * (1-Pnscope_time)

cat("P(T ∩ S) =", p_time_and_scope, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S) = 0.06

cat("P(T ∩ NS) =", p_time_and_nscope, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ NS) = 0.28

cat("P(NT ∩ S) =", p_ntime_and_scope, "\n")

#> P(NT ∩ S) = 0.24

cat("P(NT ∩ NS) =", p_ntime_and_scope, "\n")

#> P(NT ∩ NS) = 0.24


Assignment II:
Using the Venn diagram above, answer the following questions:
1-What is the percentage of customers using all three devices?:

p_customers_three_devices <- 0.5
p_customers_three_devices

#> [1] 0.5


2-What is the percentage of customers using at least two devices?

P_customers_two_devices = (7.3/100 + 3.3/100 + 8.8/100)*100
P_customers_two_devices

#> [1] 19.4


3-What is the percentage of customers using only one device?

P_customers_one_device = (27.8/100 + 10/100 + 42.3/100) * 100
P_customers_one_device

#> [1] 80.1


Assignment III:

p_B_A  <- 0.97
p_B_nA <- 0.01
p_A <- 0.04
p_nA <- 1 - p_A

p_B <- p_B_A * p_A + p_B_nA * p_nA

p_nA_B <- (p_B_nA * p_nA) / p_B
p_A_B <- (p_B_A * p_A) / p_B

cat("P(B) =", p_B, "\n")

#> P(B) = 0.0484

cat("P(A'|B) =", p_nA_B, "\n")

#> P(A'|B) = 0.1983471

cat("P(A|B) =", p_A_B, "\n")

#> P(A|B) = 0.8016529

cat("These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about",p_nA_B *100 ,"% that the product is flawless and a probability of",p_A_B*100, "% that the product is faulty.")

#> These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.83471 % that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.16529 % that the product is faulty.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.



car_prices <- readRDS("D:/TU Hamburg/Semester_5/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")
View(car_prices)


dim(car_prices)

#> [1] 181  22


1-The data has 181 rows and 22 columns.

head(car_prices)



  



2- The data types I could see are double and char datatypes. The numbers datatypes are double, however, string datatypes are char

lm_price <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices)
summary(lm_price)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



confint(lm_price, level = 0.95)

#>                              2.5 %       97.5 %
#> (Intercept)          -6.683134e+04 -5708.591461
#> aspirationturbo      -2.123031e+02  3904.715423
#> doornumbertwo        -8.880057e+02  1373.051204
#> carbodyhardtop       -6.508183e+03  -875.302661
#> carbodyhatchback     -5.792190e+03  -896.479709
#> carbodysedan         -4.973242e+03   387.602227
#> carbodywagon         -6.373755e+03  -482.087396
#> drivewheelfwd        -2.632717e+03  1623.588215
#> drivewheelrwd        -2.522030e+03  2491.138949
#> enginelocationrear    1.558895e+03 11728.088662
#> wheelbase            -2.135865e+02   153.193109
#> carlength            -1.318793e+02    72.399687
#> carwidth              2.484517e+02  1215.185989
#> carheight            -1.428819e+02   389.272214
#> curbweight           -9.086424e-01     6.132334
#> enginetypedohcv      -1.793062e+04   846.708835
#> enginetypel          -2.552383e+03  4509.878243
#> enginetypeohc         1.500996e+03  5189.507548
#> enginetypeohcf       -2.240453e+03  4186.291965
#> enginetypeohcv       -8.666335e+03 -3778.310183
#> cylindernumberfive   -1.769255e+04 -5756.526294
#> cylindernumberfour   -1.782963e+04 -5269.025514
#> cylindernumbersix    -1.159348e+04 -2709.316066
#> cylindernumberthree  -1.358731e+04  4949.451134
#> cylindernumbertwelve -1.941739e+04 -2827.032165
#> enginesize            7.347203e+01   178.396665
#> fuelsystem2bbl       -1.569500e+03  1923.771576
#> fuelsystemmfi        -8.134945e+03  2052.909867
#> fuelsystemmpfi       -1.620436e+03  2338.991505
#> fuelsystemspdi       -5.239202e+03   151.421288
#> fuelsystemspfi       -4.425440e+03  5454.972678
#> boreratio            -4.552905e+03  1939.424404
#> stroke               -6.351094e+03 -2703.179801
#> compressionratio     -1.836863e+03   361.059971
#> horsepower           -3.459530e+01    55.182371
#> peakrpm               1.272152e+00     3.778780
#> citympg              -4.197613e+02   239.056414
#> highwaympg           -1.755422e+02   485.258537


3 - Factors relevant to car prices are horsepower, engine size, aspiration turbo and fuel system
4.1 - engine size , and the data type it can take is double and the values it can take are double

lm_one_regessor <- lm(price ~ enginesize, data = car_prices)
summary(lm_one_regessor)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginesize, data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -10818.6  -1969.6   -168.6   1494.0  14393.9 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) -8622.296    873.535  -9.871   <2e-16 ***
#> enginesize    170.064      6.523  26.073   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 3694 on 179 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.7916, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7904 
#> F-statistic: 679.8 on 1 and 179 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


4.2- The price increases with the increase in the engine size according according to the estimate value 170.064. Therefore, the relation between the price and the enginesize is formulated as: price = 170.064 * enginesize - 8622.296

sprintf("Adjusted R^2: %.2f", broom::glance(lm_price)$adj.r.squared)

#> [1] "Adjusted R^2: 0.93"

# AIC
sprintf("AIC: %.2f", AIC(lm_one_regessor))

#> [1] "AIC: 3491.25"

# BIC
sprintf("BIC: %.2f", BIC(lm_one_regessor))

#> [1] "BIC: 3500.85"


4.3- According to the AIC and BIC and Adjusted R^2, it is recognized that the engine size has a statistical significance with respect to the price.

library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

car_prices %>% 
mutate(seat_heating = TRUE)



  




lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices)
summary(lm_all)

#>

5 - it seems that the new variable seat_heating has no effect on the price as it is all value is TRUE, therefore it did not affect the price in this sample. Therefore, it has no coefficient,

title: Regression Discontinuity
text:
Note
